reference.shortdesc: The equation-figure element represents an equation that functions as a form of figure or display.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: Display equations can have titles, descriptions, figure groups, and all other figure components. The direct children of equation-figure can be the equation content itself (for example, mathml or an image reference), or it can be one or more equation-block elements, along with other elements allowed within figures.
When an equation-figure element has multiple direct child mathml, equation-block, image, or pre elements, each child represents an alternative form of the equation.

draft-comment.author: nancylph
draft-comment.p: I added equation-block as another direct child that could be used as a form, since that seems as though it can be the case.

section.p: When the intent is to have equations combined with other commentary within an equation-figure, the recommended best practice is to use child equation-block elements to contain the equations and clearly distinguish them from the commentary.

section.title: Rendering expectations
section.p: Display equations can be numbered if desired, either through standard figure numbering, or through use of the equation-number element within equation-block.
section.draft-comment: I'm not sure how to interpret this. Is it an instruction that processors need to give authors a way to indicate that numbering is desired? Or could this be more simply stated as "Display equations might be numbered"? Or, is this based on the presence of equation-number, in which case we should be explicit that it is numbered when equation-number is used?

draft-comment.author: nancylph
draft-comment.p: I changed this from the original "Display equations are intended to be numbered when numbering is desired." both to address Robert's comment above, and because it seems to me that numbering could be achieved either through numbering the equation-block, or numbering the figure, and I don't think we can mandate which one to use.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: Processors are free to choose the form or forms that they use in deliverables from among the mathml, equation-block, image, or pre elements contained in the equation-figure. For example, if there is both an image and MathML markup, an HTML-generating processor could generate both the image reference and the MathML with appropriate HTML class or id values to enable dynamic rendering based on browser capability. All other direct-child elements of equation-figure are treated normally.
section.draft-comment: We say "all other" without explicitly listing what is "other" â€“ only a for-example that has images and mathml, but leaves out the pre element described earlier in the topic.

draft-comment.author: nancylph
draft-comment.p: I added specific mentions of mathml, equation-block, image and pre; I think the 'all other' refers to all the other direct children of equation-figure, of which there are many, and which appear to don't operate as forms.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The equation-figure element is specialized from fig. It is defined in the equation domain module.
